401.heading: You’re not eligible to use this service
401.lede: Based on the answers you’ve given, you currently can’t use this service.
401.lede_additional:
Visit GOV.UK for more information on [making child arrangements](https://www.gov.uk/looking-after-children-divorce).

Thank you for your time.

403.heading: This service is not available
403.lede: This service is currently in private beta and not available to you.
403.lede_additional: Visit GOV.UK for more information on [making child arrangements](https://www.gov.uk/looking-after-children-divorce).

404.heading: This page can’t be found
404.lede: Please check you’ve entered the correct web address.

500.heading: Sorry, we’re currently experiencing technical difficulties

CookieMessage.value: We uses cookies to make the site simpler. [Find out more about cookies]({app:urls:route:cookies})

collaborative-law-resources.body:
Read more about the [collaborative law process](http://www.resolution.org.uk/editorial.asp?page_id=1164)

[Find a collaborative lawyer](http://www.resolution.org.uk/memberSearch.asp?page_id=64)
collaborative-law-resources.heading: Collaborative law resources

collaborative-law-step-1.body:
Both you and the other parent will need to hire your own lawyer. A lawyer will be expensive so try and get a quote or ask if they offer a fixed fee for the collaborative process.

Some lawyers offer free 30-minute consultations or you can [check if you can get free legal help](https://www.lawworks.org.uk/legal-advice-individuals).
collaborative-law-step-1.cost_description: Fees may vary depending on your location and the experience of the lawyer. How long you need will depend on your situation.
collaborative-law-step-1.heading: Hire a lawyer

collaborative-law-step-2.body:
Your lawyer will first want to meet with you to discuss the case. They’ll need to know more about your situation and what you want to achieve from the process.

Your lawyer and the other parent’s lawyer will then contact each other so they can plan for your first collaborative meeting.
collaborative-law-step-2.heading: Meet with your lawyer

collaborative-law-step-3.body:
Before the meeting starts everyone must sign a contract that commits both parties to resolving the issues out of court.

The contract also states that if the case does go to court both you and the other parent must hire new lawyers. This means it’s in everyone’s interests to make sure the negotiations don’t break down.

Before you start to negotiate your lawyers will ask you and the other parent to share your priorities and concerns.
collaborative-law-step-3.heading: Attend first meeting

collaborative-law-step-4.body:
Collaborative law is a flexible process so how many meetings you’ll need to reach an agreement will depend on your situation.

### If you agree at the first meeting

Your lawyers will write down what’s been agreed in a document. The document isn’t legally binding but both you and the other parent will need to sign it.

If you want to make the document legally binding you can ask your lawyers to draft a [consent order](https://www.gov.uk/looking-after-children-divorce/if-you-agree). This isn’t usually necessary but ask your lawyer for advice.

### If there’s no agreement at the first meeting

You and the other parent must meet with your lawyers to discuss the unresolved issues. A date is then set for a second meeting.

### If there’s still no agreement

If it looks like you won’t be able to reach an agreement, you and the other parent may need to consider [going to court]({app:urls:route:going_to_court}).
collaborative-law-step-4.heading: Sign the agreement or set a date for next meeting

cookies-body.body:
This service puts small files (known as ‘cookies’) onto your computer.

The cookies help us:

- understand how you use the service, so we can make improvements
- remember what notifications you’ve seen so you’re not shown them again

> The cookies aren’t used to identify you personally.

Find out [how to manage cookies](http://www.aboutcookies.org/).

cookies-ga.body:
We use Google Analytics to collect information about how you use the service. This information helps us to update and improve the service.

Google Analytics stores information about:

- the pages you visit
- how long you spend on each page
- how you got to the service
- what you click on while you’re using the service

> We don’t allow Google to use or share our analytics data.

You can [opt out of Google Analytics cookies](https://tools.google.com/dlpage/gaoptout).
cookies-ga.cookie_description: A randomly generated reference is used to identify unique users and inform referring sites, visitor and session counts
cookies-ga.heading: Google Analytics cookie

cookies-introductory-message.body: When you first use the service, you may see a pop‑up ‘welcome’ message. Once you’ve seen the message, we store a cookie on your computer so it knows not to show it again.
cookies-introductory-message.cookie_description: Saves a message to let us know you’ve seen our cookie message
cookies-introductory-message.heading: Introductory message cookie

cookies-youtube.body: We use YouTube to provide videos on some pages of the service. YouTube sets cookies when you visit one of these pages.
cookies-youtube.cookie_description: Randomly generated number that identifies your browser
cookies-youtube.cookie_description_2: Lets YouTube count the views of embedded YouTube videos
cookies-youtube.heading: YouTube videos

emotional-support-counselling.body:
A professional counsellor can help you understand issues such as:

- how to reduce emotional stress
- the effect disputes have on your children
- why your relationship with the other parent ended

[Contact the Samaritans](http://www.samaritans.org/how-we-can-help-you/contact-us) if you need to speak to someone urgently.
emotional-support-counselling.cost_description: Cost based on a 50-minute session. Fees may vary depending on your location and the experience of the counsellor. Some counsellors offer reductions if you’re unemployed or on a low income.
emotional-support-counselling.heading: Counselling

emotional-support-offline.body: Look for a [family meet-up group](https://www.meetup.com/find/parents-family/) or [single parents network](https://www.meetup.com/find/?allMeetups=false&keywords=single+parent+support&radius=50&userFreeform=London%2C+United+Kingdom&mcId=z1012717&mcName=London%2C+England%2C+GB&sort=default&eventFilter=mysugg) in your area. Both work in the same way as forums but the focus is usually on meeting face to face.
emotional-support-offline.heading: Find a group near you

emotional-support-online.body:
Online forums allow you to share your story, tell people how you’re feeling and discuss any concerns you have.

You can get advice from others by posting a question or sharing your story.

The following are examples of helpful forums:

- [Parent Connection](http://www.theparentconnection.org.uk/posts)
- [Dad.info](https://www.dad.info/forum/index)
- [Netmums](https://www.netmums.com/coffeehouse/)
- [Wikivorce](https://www.wikivorce.com/divorce/About-Us.html)
- [Gingerbread](https://gingerbread.org.uk/Forum/default.aspx)
emotional-support-online.heading: Use online forums

emotional-support-peers.body:
Your family and friends are likely to be the greatest source of support.

You can also try using online forums or attending group meetings to speak with people who have been through a similar experience.
emotional-support-peers.heading: Peer support

emotional-support-professional.body: You should consider professional advice (for example seeing a counsellor or attending meetings) if you feel you’re struggling to cope.
emotional-support-professional.heading: Professional advice

emotional-support-readiness.body:
Emotional readiness is being able to put aside your own feelings and any negative thoughts about the other parent. If you’re emotionally ready you’ll have a better chance of making an agreement that’s in the best interests of your children.

The Children and Family Court Advisory and Support Service (Cafcass) has more information on what you need to do to [become emotionally ready](https://www.cafcass.gov.uk/grown-ups/listening-to-your-child-after-separation.aspx).
emotional-support-readiness.heading: Emotional readiness

emotional-support-resources.body:
[Find out more about counselling](http://www.counselling-directory.org.uk/separation.html)

Relate has a [free online chat service](https://www.relate.org.uk/relationship-help/talk-someone/live-chat-counsellor). Sessions last around 25 minutes.

Relate also has a [telephone service](https://www.relate.org.uk/relationship-help/talk-someone/telephone-counselling) that costs £55 per hour.

[Getting it right for children](http://theparentconnection.org.uk/programmes/programmes/getting-it-right-for-children-when-parents-part) is a free programme which uses real life situations to show how things can go wrong - and how you can do them better.
emotional-support-resources.heading: Getting emotional support resources

emotional-support-spip.body:
The [Separated Parents Information Programme](https://www.cafcass.gov.uk/grown-ups/separated-parents-information-programme-%28spip%29.aspx) helps you understand how to put your children first and manage disputes with the other parent.

A judge may direct you to attend a SPIP if you take your case to court. You won’t go to the same meeting as the other parent.

There are similar programmes in [Wales](http://cafcass.gov.wales/info_for_adults/working_together_for_children_course/?skip=1&lang=en) and [Scotland](http://www.relationships-scotland.org.uk/family-support/parenting-apart-groups).
emotional-support-spip.cost_description: It may be free to attend in some areas.
emotional-support-spip.heading: Parenting advice

going-to-court-resources.body:
Telephone: 01689 820272 (Resolution)  
[Check if you can get legal aid](https://checklegalaid.service.gov.uk/)  
[Find a legal adviser near you](https://www.gov.uk/find-a-legal-adviser)  
[Check if you can get free legal help](https://barprobono.org.uk/do-you-need-help.html)  
[Legal costs: free or affordable help](https://www.citizensadvice.org.uk/law-and-courts/legal-system/taking-legal-action/help-with-legal-costs-free-or-affordable-help/)
going-to-court-resources.heading: Going to court resources

going-to-court-step-1.body:
### Hire a lawyer

A lawyer will be expensive but they’ll handle the legal aspects of the case and represent you in court.

They may try and negotiate a deal out of court with the other parent or recommend you move to step 2 straight away.

[Find a legal adviser](http://solicitors.lawsociety.org.uk/)

### Represent yourself

You may choose to represent yourself because you’d prefer to speak to the judge directly or because you can’t afford the legal fees.

GOV.UK has more information on [how to represent yourself in court](https://www.gov.uk/represent-yourself-in-court/overview).

The [Personal Support Unit (PSU)](https://www.thepsu.org/about-us/) provides help for every stage of the court process for those without a lawyer.

[Find a free legal advice clinic](https://www.lawworks.org.uk/legal-advice-individuals/find-legal-advice-clinic-near-you)
going-to-court-step-1.cost_description: Fees may vary depending on your location and the experience of the lawyer. How long you need will depend on your situation. Some lawyers offer free 30-minute consultations or you can [check if you can get free legal help](https://barprobono.org.uk/do-you-need-help.html).
going-to-court-step-1.heading: Choose to hire a lawyer or represent yourself

going-to-court-step-2.body:
Before applying for a court order you must attend a [MIAM](https://staging-public.cait.dsd.io/professional-mediation), unless there’s been domestic abuse or social services are already involved in your situation.

The MIAM will assess whether mediation is right for you and if you can agree arrangements out of court.

You will need to [find a mediator](https://www.familymediationcouncil.org.uk/find-local-mediator/) to book a MIAM.

Only authorised mediators can carry out a MIAM. Check with the mediator before you book.
going-to-court-step-2.cost: Average cost of MIAM per person
going-to-court-step-2.cost_description: Estimated fees may vary depending on your location and the experience of the mediator. Some mediators offer reductions if you’re unemployed or on a low income. It may be cheaper if you attend together.
going-to-court-step-2.heading: Attend a Mediation Information and Assessment Meeting (MIAM)

going-to-court-step-3.body:
Fill in the C100 form to [apply for a court order](https://www.gov.uk/looking-after-children-divorce/apply-for-court-order) and send it to your nearest family court. It costs £215 to apply.

> You must give a brief summary of your position and what you want to achieve from the hearing. This is sometimes known as a ‘position statement’.

You’ll need to make a separate application if you wish to discuss any other issues in court (for example your finances).
The court will set a date for a First Hearing Dispute Resolution Appointment (FHDRA). It’ll take about 4 weeks after you apply to get a date.

An advisor from the [Children and Family Court Advisory and Support Service (Cafcass)](https://www.cafcass.gov.uk/default.aspx) will provide a report before the first hearing.

A Cafcass report includes:

- a social services and criminal record check on you and the other parent
- details of your family’s current arrangements
- a summary of any other issues the court needs to be aware of

Cafcass will also contact you before the first hearing with more information about what to do on the day.

[Watch video for more details](#c_video_player)
going-to-court-step-3.cost_description: Only applicant needs to pay the fee.
going-to-court-step-3.heading: Apply for a court order

going-to-court-step-4.body:
At the first hearing the court will see if there’s still a chance you can reach an agreement with the other parent.

### If you can reach an agreement

The judge will end the process and write a consent order setting out the details of your agreement.

### If you can’t reach an agreement

The judge will look at the issues you disagree on and set out a timetable for what will happen next.

You may be asked to try and reach an agreement again. This could be through [mediation ]({app:urls:route:professional_mediation}) or a [Separated Parents Information Programme (SPIP)](https://www.cafcass.gov.uk/grown-ups/separated-parents-information-programme-%28spip%29.aspx).

Your case may be put on hold (adjourned) if the judge needs more time to decide what’s best for the children. The court may ask Cafcass to write another report.

A new date is then set for a final hearing. If you reach an agreement before this date the judge can stop the process.

GOV.UK has more information on [what happens if there’s no agreement at the first hearing](https://www.gov.uk/looking-after-children-divorce/after-you-apply-for-a-court-order).
going-to-court-step-4.heading: Go to court

involving-children-counselling.body: Many schools have professionals they can talk to, but some might need further help from a counsellor. The type of [counselling](http://www.counselling-directory.org.uk/childrelatedissues.html) varies depending on age and if they have any learning difficulties.
involving-children-counselling.heading: Counselling

involving-children-involving.body:
Children are more likely to adapt to new arrangements if you involve them in decisions. If they understand the situation, make sure to include them whenever possible.

You should try and make your arrangements flexible so you can take into account the changing needs of your children as they grow older.

[Find out more about involving your children](https://www.cafcass.gov.uk/grown-ups/listening-to-your-child-after-separation.aspx)
involving-children-involving.heading: Involving your children

involving-children-online-support.body:
[Voices in the Middle](https://voicesinthemiddle.org.uk/) is a website that has advice from young people in a similar situation. There’s a guide to further help if your children want it.

[Where to get emotional support for your children](https://www.sortingoutseparation.org.uk/children-parenting/childs-emotional-physical-well/)
involving-children-online-support.heading: Support online

involving-children-protecting.body:
In some situations it may not be in the child’s best interests for parents to work out child arrangements. You’ll probably need to go to court if you’re worried about the safety of you or your children.

You should [report child abuse](https://www.gov.uk/report-child-abuse) or [domestic abuse](https://www.gov.uk/report-domestic-abuse) if you have any concerns.

Read more about the [signs of child abuse](https://www.nspcc.org.uk/preventing-abuse/child-abuse-and-neglect/) and [domestic abuse](http://www.refuge.org.uk/get-help-now/help-for-women/recognising-abuse/).
involving-children-protecting.heading: Protecting your children

involving-children-seeing.body:
Your children will cope better with their situation if they have regular contact with you and the other parent, if it’s safe to do so.

[Research shows](http://theparentconnection.org.uk/articles/what-children-think-about-contact) most children think the parent who doesn’t live with them is still an important part of their family.

You can use a [child contact centre](https://www.naccc.org.uk/) if you don’t live with your children and can’t find somewhere to see them. There are around 350 across England and Wales.

> There are steps you can take if the other parent is [preventing you from seeing your children](http://www.advicenow.org.uk/guides/survival-guide-sorting-out-arrangements-your-children).
involving-children-seeing.heading: Seeing your children

involving-children-supporting.body: Your children may need extra support if they’re finding it hard to cope.
involving-children-supporting.heading: Supporting your children

lawyer-negotiation-process.body:
You might use lawyer negotiation (also known as solicitor-led negotiation) if you no longer talk to the other parent.

To begin the process both you and the other parent will need to hire your own lawyer.

Your lawyer will set up a meeting to discuss the case with you. You’ll need to explain what your issues are and the outcome you want to achieve.

After receiving instructions from you and the other parent, the lawyers will begin negotiations face-to-face. You won’t have to deal directly with the other parent at any time.

As in [collaborative law]({app:urls:route:collaborative_law}) both lawyers will try and keep the case from going to court.

Your lawyers will draw up a document for court approval once they reach an agreement that you and the other parent are happy with.They’ll then submit it to the court for consideration and approval.
lawyer-negotiation-process.cost_description: Fees may vary depending on your location and the experience of the lawyer. How long you need will depend on your situation. Some lawyers offer free 30-minute consultations or you can [check if you can get free legal help](https://www.lawworks.org.uk/legal-advice-individuals).
lawyer-negotiation-process.heading: Lawyer negotation process

FeedbackBanner__link.value: Your [feedback](https://www.surveymonkey.co.uk/r/3DXCX9L) will help us make improvements

negotiating-resources.body:
GOV.UK has information on [arranging child maintenance yourself](https://www.gov.uk/arranging-child-maintenance-yourself) that includes a [child maintenance calculator](https://www.gov.uk/calculate-your-child-maintenance).

Separated Families also has a free [online parenting plan](https://www.separatedfamilies.info/home/parenting-apart/parenting-agreements/).

The Parent Connection offers a few [tips on how to communicate with your ex](http://theparentconnection.org.uk/articles/tips-for-helping-you-communicate-with-your-ex).
negotiating-resources.heading: Negotiation resources

negotiating-tools.body:
The needs of your children must come first when negotiating arrangements. The following are flexible (unless you make them into a [consent order](https://www.wikivorce.com/divorce/Consent-Orders.html)) so you can change the details as your children grow older.

### Parenting plan

A parenting plan is a written or online plan that you use to prepare, discuss and agree child arrangements. It’s not legally binding and you can update the details as your children grow older and their needs change.

Using a parenting plan:

- helps you know what’s expected of you
- confirms your agreements (for example, where your children will live)
- works as a record for you to go back to

You can choose to use an [online parenting plan](http://www.splittingup-putkidsfirst.org.uk/home) or a plan you [can print out](https://www.cafcass.gov.uk/grown-ups/parenting-plan.aspx).

### Negotiating tools

[The Negotiations Cycle tool](https://www.separatedfamilies.info/home/parenting-apart/negotiations/) lets you break down your negotiations into 4 stages.

Gingerbread has an [arrangements factsheet](https://gingerbread.org.uk/factsheet/4/Making-arrangements-for-your-children) that includes tips on making negotiating work.

### Letter templates

Child Law Advice has a useful [letter template](http://childlawadvice.org.uk/wp-content/uploads/Residence-template-letter.pdf) if you prefer to negotiate by letter or email.
negotiating-tools.heading: Which tools and services to use

negotiating-unsuitable.body:
### Child abuse or neglect

You shouldn’t make arrangements with the other parent if you have reason to think they’re abusing or neglecting your children.

[Report child abuse](https://www.gov.uk/report-child-abuse-to-local-council) if you have any concerns and tell your children about [Childline](https://www.childline.org.uk/) so they can report any abuse themselves.

You can [report a concern about a child online](https://www.nspcc.org.uk/what-you-can-do/report-abuse/report-abuse-online/) to the National Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children (NSPCC).

[Find out more about child abuse and neglect](https://www.nspcc.org.uk/preventing-abuse/child-abuse-and-neglect/)

### Domestic violence

Negotiating with the other parent directly won’t be suitable if they pose a threat to you or your children’s safety.

[Report domestic violence](https://www.gov.uk/report-domestic-abuse) if it’s safe to do so and you think you’re a victim.

Find out more about [signs of domestic violence](http://www.refuge.org.uk/get-help-now/what-is-domestic-violence/) if you’re unsure whether you’re a victim.
negotiating-unsuitable.heading: When negotiating may not be suitable

parental-responsibility-making-decisions.body:
You don’t always need to get the consent of the other parent when making a decision, even if they also have parental responsibility.

If it’s a major decision (for example one of you wants to move abroad with your children) both parents with responsibility must agree in writing.

You can apply for a [Specific Issue Order](http://www.compactlaw.co.uk/free-legal-information/children/specific-issue-order.html) or [Prohibited Steps Order](http://www.lawandparents.co.uk/prohibited-steps-orders-effect-parents.html) if you can’t agree. A judge will then make a decision which is in your children’s best interests.
parental-responsibility-making-decisions.heading: Making decisions with the other parent

parental-responsibility-responsibilities.body:
You’re also responsible for issues such as:

- where they go to school
- how to discipline them
- agreeing to their medical treatment
- choosing, registering or changing their names

All mothers automatically have parental responsibility. A father usually does if he’s either married to the child’s mother or listed on the birth certificate.

Find out more about [who has parental responsibility](https://www.gov.uk/parental-rights-responsibilities/who-has-parental-responsibility).

You can [apply for parental responsibility](https://www.gov.uk/parental-rights-responsibilities/apply-for-parental-responsibility) if you don’t automatically have it.

> You must provide financial support for your children even if you don’t have parental responsibility.

[Arrange child maintenance yourself](https://www.gov.uk/arranging-child-maintenance-yourself)

privacy-body.body:
This includes:

- any questions or feedback you leave
- your email address (if you leave feedback)
- your IP address, and details of which version of web browser you used
information on how you use the site

This helps us to:

- improve the site by monitoring how you use it
- respond to any feedback or questions you send us, if you’ve asked us to

We can’t identify you using your data.

### Where your data is stored

Any information you provide when using the service is held by [SurveyMonkey](https://www.surveymonkey.co.uk/). Check the [SurveyMonkey privacy policy](https://www.surveymonkey.co.uk/mp/policy/privacy-policy/) to find out what it does with your information.

### Links to other websites

This privacy policy only applies to this service. It doesn’t cover the other services and websites that we link to.

### Following a link to another website

If you go to another website from this service, read the privacy policy on that website to find out what it does with your information.

### Following a link to this service from another website

If you come to this service from another website, we may receive personal information about you from the other website. Read the privacy policy of that website to find out more.

professional-mediation-other.body:
### Shuttle mediation

Your mediator may suggest you and the other parent sit in separate rooms and the mediator ‘shuttle’ between you. This is a good option if you’d prefer not to meet the other parent face-to-face or don’t feel safe to do so.

Shuttle mediation is usually more expensive than standard mediation because it’s a longer process.

### Lawyer-assisted mediation

This is different to standard mediation because you and the other parent both hire lawyers who attend the sessions with you. You can also hire lawyers to help with shuttle mediation.

As mediators can’t offer legal advice you may want to choose this option if you have a lot of complex legal issues to resolve.

You’ll need to consider the additional cost of a lawyer if you select this option.

### Family mediation

Parents with children over 10 years old are encouraged to include them in the process so the mediator can hear their opinion.

Talk with a mediator about whether it’s suitable to involve your children in your situation and ask your child if they’re happy to take part.

Check if your mediator is qualified to offer this service before booking.
professional-mediation-other.heading: Other types of mediation

professional-mediation-resources.body:
The Family Mediation Council has more information on the [mediation process](https://www.familymediationcouncil.org.uk/family-mediation/) and how it can benefit you.

The [Separated Parents Information Programme](https://www.cafcass.gov.uk/grown-ups/separated-parents-information-programme-(spip).aspx) helps you understand how to put your children first and manage disputes with the other parent. There are similar programmes in [Wales](http://cafcass.gov.wales/info_for_adults/working_together_for_children_course/?skip=1&lang=en) and [Scotland](http://www.relationships-scotland.org.uk/family-support/parenting-apart-groups).

Download a [mediation information pack](https://www.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/489124/family-mediation-leaflet.pdf) from the Ministry of Justice.

Advice Now has a [guide to using mediation](http://www.advicenow.org.uk/guides/survival-guide-using-family-mediation-after-break) following separation.

Find out more about [lawyer-assisted mediation](http://www.divorce.co.uk/divorce-approaches/mediation-with-lawyers)

[Find a local mediator](https://www.familymediationcouncil.org.uk/find-local-mediator/)
professional-mediation-resources.heading: Professional mediation resources

professional-mediation-step-1.body:
Mediator rates can vary depending on their experience and your location. Some offer reductions if you’re unemployed or on a low income.

Check with the mediator before booking and don’t be afraid to shop around.
professional-mediation-step-1.heading: Find a mediator

professional-mediation-step-2.body:
You must first meet with a mediator to check if mediation is right for you. This is called a pre-mediation meeting.

If you or the other parent wants to go to [court]({app:urls:route:going_to_court}) this initial meeting is called a [Mediation Information and Assessment Meeting (MIAM)](https://www.familymediationcouncil.org.uk/family-mediation/assessment-meeting-miam/).

The parent applying to court is legally required to show they’ve considered mediation by attending a MIAM, unless [they’re exempt](https://www.familymediationcouncil.org.uk/family-mediation/assessment-meeting-miam/miams-exemptions/). The other parent is also expected to attend.

At either meeting the mediator will explain:

- how mediation works
- the benefits
- whether it’s right for you
- the likely costs
- if you’re eligible for free mediation through [legal aid](https://checklegalaid.service.gov.uk/)

Only authorised mediators can carry out a MIAM. Check with the mediator before you book.
professional-mediation-step-2.cost: Average cost of MIAM per person
professional-mediation-step-2.cost_description: Estimated fees may vary depending on your location and the experience of the mediator. Some mediators offer reductions if you’re unemployed or on a low income. It may also be cheaper if you attend together.
professional-mediation-step-2.heading: Book initial meeting with mediator

professional-mediation-step-3.body:
Mediation usually takes place face-to-face with the other parent over several sessions. Each session lasts about 90 minutes.

You can choose to have mediation:

- in the same room
- in different rooms (shuttle mediation)
- on different days
- with your children (family mediation)
- with a lawyer (lawyer-assisted mediation)
professional-mediation-step-3.cost: Average cost of mediation per person
professional-mediation-step-3.cost_description: Estimated cost based on an average of __3__ sessions. Fees may vary depending on your location and the experience of the mediator. Some mediators offer reductions if you’re unemployed or on a low income.
professional-mediation-step-3.heading: Attend mediation sessions

professional-mediation-step-4.body:
If  you both reach an agreement the mediator will write down the details. This isn’t legally binding but is flexible so you can update it if your situation changes.

### Making your agreement legally binding

You can ask a lawyer to draft a consent order if you or the other parent prefer to make your agreement legally binding.

This can be useful if your arrangements are long and complex or you think you need a more formal agreement with the other parent.

GOV.UK has more information about consent orders and [making your agreement legally binding](https://www.gov.uk/looking-after-children-divorce/if-you-agree).
professional-mediation-step-4.heading: Get agreement in writing

professional-mediation-unsuitable.body:
### Child abuse or neglect

You shouldn’t attend mediation with the other parent if you think they’re abusing or neglecting your children.

[Report child abuse](https://www.gov.uk/report-child-abuse-to-local-council) if you have any concerns and tell your children about [Childline](https://www.childline.org.uk/) so they can report any abuse themselves.

You can [report a concern about a child online](https://www.nspcc.org.uk/what-you-can-do/report-abuse/report-abuse-online/) to the National Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children (NSPCC).

[Find out more about child abuse and neglect](https://www.nspcc.org.uk/preventing-abuse/child-abuse-and-neglect/)

### Domestic violence

Mediation with the other parent is not likely to be suitable if you think they pose a threat to you or your children’s safety.

[Report domestic violence](https://www.gov.uk/report-domestic-abuse) if it’s safe to do so and you think you’re a victim.

Find out more about [signs of domestic violence](http://www.refuge.org.uk/get-help-now/what-is-domestic-violence/) if you’re unsure whether you’re a victim.
professional-mediation-unsuitable.heading: When mediation may not be suitable

reaching-collection.title: Reaching an agreement
reaching-collection.title_nav: Other ways to reach an agreement

route:accepted.heading: You’re eligible to use this service
route:accepted.lede: This service is currently in ‘private beta’. This means you’re looking at the first version of it.
route:accepted.lede_additional:
A service in ‘private beta’ isn’t open to everyone or may not work for everyone. We do this so we can test and improve the service before releasing it to more people.

After using the service, please give your feedback using the link at the top of the page.

We’ll send you a reminder by email if you forget to leave feedback.

cons: won’t work unless you and the other parent trust each other equally
route:collaborative_law.heading: Collaborative law
route:collaborative_law.lede: Collaborative lawyers work with you and the other parent to resolve your issues out of court. You each hire a lawyer then all meet to negotiate face-to-face.
route:collaborative_law.lede_additional: The collaborative process involves several steps but is usually quicker and cheaper than going to court.
pros: everyone is committed to not going to court
quicker and less stressful than court
you and the other parent set the agenda
good for your children to see their parents working together
route:collaborative_law.usp: You can still communicate with the other parent but have complex legal issues to resolve.

route:emotional_support.heading: Getting emotional support
route:emotional_support.lede: Emotional support can help you get through the stress of making child arrangements.
route:emotional_support.lede_additional: You’re more likely to reach an agreement if you’re emotionally ready and know where to get support if you need it.

cons: court process takes a long time
you’re not in control - a judge will make the decision
can be more stressful for your children
increased chance of conflict between you and the other parent
route:going_to_court.heading: Going to court
route:going_to_court.lede: You’ll need to go to court if you’ve tried other suitable options and still can’t agree arrangements, or you’re worried about the safety of you or your children.
route:going_to_court.lede_additional: The court process involves several steps and can take a long time.
route:going_to_court.usp: You want a court to make a decision for you or you have concerns about domestic abuse or child neglect.

concerns: arranging times your children spend with you
route:involving_children.heading: Putting your children first
route:involving_children.lede: The needs of your children should come first when you make child arrangements with the other parent.
route:involving_children.lede_additional: Your children will feel happier if they have regular contact with you and the other parent, if it’s safe to do so. If they understand the situation, involve them in the decision-making.
route:involving_children.summary_lede_additional: Your children will feel happier if they have regular contact with you and the other parent, and know where to get extra support if they need it. If they understand the situation, involve them in the decision-making.

cons: can be seen as a confrontational approach
you may feel you’re not in control
route:lawyer_negotiation.heading: Lawyer negotiation
route:lawyer_negotiation.lede: You don’t have to deal directly with the other parent if you choose this option. You each hire a lawyer to negotiate arrangements for you.
route:lawyer_negotiation.lede_additional: It can be an expensive process but some parents find having experienced legal help reassuring.
pros: everyone is committed to not going to court
quicker and less stressful than court
you don’t deal directly with the other parent
route:lawyer_negotiation.usp: Your relationship is still difficult and you’d prefer not to meet, or there’s a lack of trust.

cons: you’ll need a consent order to make agreement legally binding
process heavily relies on parent co-operation
route:negotiating_between_parents.heading: Negotiation tools and services
route:negotiating_between_parents.lede: If there are no safety concerns, the cheapest and easiest way to make arrangements is to negotiate with the other parent. There are free tools and services that can help you.
pros: you and the other parent are in control
route:negotiating_between_parents.usp: You both still communicate and agree on the majority of issues but may benefit from using a tool such as a parenting plan.

concerns: making decisions with the other parent
route:parental_responsibility.heading: Your parental responsibility
route:parental_responsibility.lede: Parental responsibility is a term that means you have legal rights and duties relating to your children’s upbringing.
route:parental_responsibility.lede_additional: It doesn’t mean you have a right to spend time with your children (if you don’t live with them), but the other parent must update you on their well-being.

route:privacy.heading: Privacy policy
route:privacy.lede: When you use this service certain information or data about you is collected.

cons: you’ll need a consent order to make agreement legally binding
process won’t work unless parents can co-operate
route:professional_mediation.heading: Professional mediation
route:professional_mediation.lede: Mediation sessions are run by professionals who help you try and reach an agreement without going to court.
route:professional_mediation.lede_additional: Mediation isn’t relationship counselling and you don’t have to be in the same room as the other parent.
pros: it’s quicker than court in most cases
route:professional_mediation.summary_lede: Mediation sessions are run by professionals who help you try and reach an agreement without going to court. It isn’t relationship counselling and you don’t have to be in the same room as the other parent.
route:professional_mediation.usp: You both want to reach an agreement but need help from someone who is independent.

route:summary.heading: Get help with child arrangements
route:summary.lede: Use this guide if you need to make or change child arrangements (also known as custody or contact) with the other parent. For example, you may need to decide where your children will live or rearrange the times they see you.

route:terms_conditions.heading: Terms and conditions
route:terms_conditions.lede: By using this service you agree to these terms and conditions.

ServicePhase__text.value: This is the first version of the service

summary-intro.body:
This guide contains help on:

#### Preparing to make arrangements

Includes information on where to find emotional support and how to put your children’s needs first.

#### Reaching an agreement

Includes information on the different options you can use (such as mediation) to help you make an arrangement.

terms-conditions-phase.body:
This service is currently in ‘private beta’. This means you’re looking at the first version of it.

A service in ‘private beta’ isn’t open to everyone or may not work for everyone. We do this so we can test and improve the service before releasing it to more people.
terms-conditions-phase.heading: Private beta

terms-conditions-responsibility.body:
The Ministry of Justice (MoJ) runs this service.

We try to make sure the information we provide is accurate and complete and the service is always available and virus free.

The MoJ accepts no liability for:

- you being unable to access the service (for example due to high demand or because we've taken it down for maintenance)
- indirect damages arising from you using the service or relying on its content
- the content and availability of external websites that link to the service or which link from it
terms-conditions-responsibility.heading: Responsibility for the service
